question: Consider the linear operator $F:\mathbb{R}^2 \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ such that $F(x,y)=(x+2y,2x+3y)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(-3x+2y, 2x-y)$
answer3: $F^{-1}$ is defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, -2x+y)$ and is not a symmetric operator
answer4: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, 2x-y)$

The conjunction of equations $\dfrac{2x-1}{3}=2-y=\dfrac{z+3}{2}$ determine a straight line $r$. 
Choose the right answer:
answer1: $r$ has the direction of $v=\bigg(\dfrac{3}{2}, -1, 2\bigg)$ and contains the point $P=\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}, 2, -3\bigg)$.
answer2: $r$ has the direction of $v=(3, 1, 2)$ and contains the point $P=(1, 2, -3)$.

question: Choose the true statement.

question: Consider the linear operator $F:\mathbb{R}^2 \longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^2$ such that $F(x,y)=(x+2y,2x+3y)$. Choose the right answer:
answer1: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(-3x+2y, 2x-y)$
answer3: $F^{-1}$ is defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, -2x+y)$ and is not a symmetric operator
answer4: $F^{-1}$ is a symmetric operator defined by $F^{-1}(x,y)=(3x-2y, 2x-y)$

question:
Let $H=\left\{\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      a & b \\
	 0 & a^2
			\end{array}\right]: a,b \in \mathbb{R}\right\}$. Choose the right answer.
answer1:
$H$ is not a subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$ because $\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      3 & 2 \\
	 0 & 9
			\end{array}\right] + \left[\begin{array}{rr}
      1 & 0 \\
	 0 & 1
			\end{array}\right] \notin H$
answer2:
$H$ is a subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$ because $\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      0 & 0 \\
	 0 & 0
			\end{array}\right] \in H$
answer3:
Since $ 1\times\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      a & b \\
	 0 & a^2
			\end{array}\right] \in H$, than $H$ is a subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$
answer4:
$H$ is not a  subspace of $M_{2\times 2}(\mathbb{R})$ because $\left[\begin{array}{rr}
      2 & 0 \\
	 0 & 6
			\end{array}\right] + \left[\begin{array}{rr}
      1 & 0 \\
	 0 & 1
			\end{array}\right] \notin H$

Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
x & + & y & - & z & + & w & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x+y,\,x-y-1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

\end{cases}$$

Find the solutions of the following linear system depending on the parameters $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$:
$$\begin{cases}
-x & + & y & + & z & = & a \\
&  & y & + & 3z & = & b \\
x &  &  & + & z & = & c
\end{cases}$$
answer1: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(a-b+2c,\,3a-2b+3c,\,-a+b-c\right)$.
answer3:
The system has no solution for $a\neq 0$. 
If $a=0$ and for every value of $b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has a unique solution, which is $\left(2c-b,\,3c-2b,\,b-c\right)$.
answer4: For every value of $a,b,c\in\mathbb{R}$, the system has $\left(1,\,1,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.

A population of $600$ semiconductor wafers contains wafers from three lots. The wafers are categorised by lot and by whether they conform to a thickness specification. The following table presents the number of wafers in each category.

$$\begin{array}{l c c} 
\hline
\text{Lot} & \text{Conforming} & \text{Nonconforming} \\ 
\hline
A & 88  & 12 \\ 
B & 165 & 35 \\ 
C & 260 & 40 \\ 
\hline
\end{array}$$

If the wafer is conforming, what is the probability that it is from Lot $A$?

Ralph Edmund loves steaks and potatoes. Therefore, he has decided to go on a steady diet of only these two foods (plus some liquids and vitamin supplements) for all his meals. Ralph realizes that this isn't the healthiest diet, so he wants to make sure that he eats the right quantities of the two foods to satisfy some key nutritional requirements. He has obtained the following nutritional and cost information:

\[
\begin{array}{|l|c|c|c|}
\hline
%& \multicolumn{2}{c|}{Grams of ingredient per serving} &\\
\text{Ingredient} & \text{Steak (gr. per serving)} & \text{Potatoes (gr. per serving)} & \text{Daily Requirements (gr.)} \\
\hline
\text{Carbohydrates} & 5 & 15 & \geq 50 \\
\text{Protein} & 20 & 5 & \geq 40 \\
\text{Fat} & 15 & 2 & \leq 60 \\
\hline
\text{Cost per serving} & 4 & 2 &  \\
\hline
\end{array}
\]

How does the Linear Programming (LP) model should be formalized to allow planning the Ralph's diet?

Find the solution of the following system:
$$\begin{cases}
&x &+ &y &+ &z &= &0 \\ 
&-x &- &y &+ &2z &= &-1 \\ 
&x &+ &y &- &5z &= &2
\end{cases}$$
answer1:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on one parameter:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3},y, -\frac{1}{3}\right),\, \forall y\in\mathbb{R}$$.
answer2:
The system has infinitely many solutions depending on two parameters:
$$\left( -y+\dfrac{1}{3}z,y, z\right),\, \forall y,z\in\mathbb{R}$$.

question:
Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x &  &  &+ &4z &= &0 \\ 
3x &- &4y &+ &12z &= &0 \\ 
x &- &2y &+ &5z &= &0
\end{cases}$$
answer1: The system has $\left(-2z,\,\frac{3z}{2},\,z\right)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(-4,3,2\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(-2z+y,y,z\right)$ as solution for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

Solve the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & 2y & - & 3z & + & w & = & -2 \\
3x & - & y & - & 2z & - & 4w & = & 1 \\
2x & + & 3y & - & 5z & + & w & = & -3 \\
x & + & y & - & z & + & w & = & -2
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(z+w,\,z-w-1,\,z,\,w\right)$ as solution for all $z,w\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer3: The system has $\left(1,\,2,\,2,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer4: The system has $\left(x,\,y,\,x+y,\,x-y-1\right)$ as solution for all $x,y\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: Indicate which of the following is a subspace of $\mathbb{R}^3$.

Find the solutions of the following linear system:
$$\begin{cases}
2x & + & y & - & 4z & = & 2 \\ 
-x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\ 
x & + & 5y & - & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $(5,3,3)$ as unique solution.
answer3: The system has $(10,5,6)$ as unique solution.
answer4: The system has $(\frac{5}{3}z,1+\frac{2}{3}z,z)$ as solution for every $z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question: The significance level for a hypothesis test is $0.05$. Choose the correct interpretation.
answer1: The probability to make a Type $I$ error is $0.05$.
answer2: The probability of making a Type $II$ error is $0.95$.
answer3: The probability that the sample is randomly selected is $0.05$.
answer4: The probability, that the null hypothesis will be rejected is $0.05$.

Solve the linear system
$$\begin{cases}
x & + & y & + & z & = & 1 \\
3x & - & y & - & z & = & 4 \\
x & + & 5y & + & 5z & = & -1
\end{cases}$$
answer2: The system has $\left(0,\,0,\,1\right)$ as its unique solution.
answer3: The system has $\left(x,\,x,\,-2x+1\right)$ as solution for every $x\in\mathbb{R}$.
answer4: The system has $\left(\frac{5}{4},\,y,\,z\right)$ as solution for every $y,z\in\mathbb{R}$.

question:
For every $m\in\mathbb{R}$, consider the line $r$ of equation $x+my=-3$ and the line $s$ of equation $mx+4y=6$.
Describe the mutual position of $r$ and $s$ with respect to the value of $m$.
answer1: The lines $r$ and $s$ are equal if $m=-2$, parallel if $m=2$, and secant otherwise.
answer2: The lines $r$ and $s$ are equal if $m=2$, parallel if $m=-2$, and secant otherwise.
answer3: The lines $r$ and $s$ are secant for every $m$.
answer4: The lines $r$ and $s$ are parallel for every $m$.

question:

\[
f:\mathbb{R}^{2}\rightarrow\mathbb{R},\text{ }f(x,y)=x^{2}+y^{3}%
\].
Simplify $i^2+8i^3+i^5-2i^7$.

For which values of $m\in\mathbb{R}$ does the following linear system have infinitely many solutions?
$$\left\{\begin{array}{cccccccc}
3x & + & y & - & z & = & 1\\
x & - & 2y & + & 2z & = & m\\
x & + & y & - & z & = & 1\\
\end{array}\right.$$
answer4: There is no $m\in\mathbb{R}$ for which the linear system has infinitely many solutions.

question: Assume that $u$, $v$ and $w$ are linearly independent vectors. Choose the wrong answer.
answer4: $\left\{u,v\right\}$ is a linearly independent set of vectors

question:
Consider the matrix 
$$A_k=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}
 1  & 1  & 0 \\
  -1 & -k  & k-1 \\
  3 & 2  & 2k+1
\end{array}\right]$$
and denote by $L(A_k)$ the space of the rows of the matrix $A_k$. Which of the following statements is true?
answer1: If $k\in \mathbb{R}\backslash \{0, 1\}$ then the dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$
answer2: The dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$ for every $k\in \mathbb{R}$
answer3: If $k\in \mathbb{R}\backslash \{0\}$ then the dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$
answer4: If $k\in \mathbb{R}\backslash \{0, -1\}$ then the dimension of $L(A_k)$ is $3$

question: Choose the true statement.
answer1: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer2: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^4$ is $\left\{(0,0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer3: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^2\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0)\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
answer4: If the kernel of a linear transformation $T:\mathbb{R}^3\longrightarrow \mathbb{R}^3$ is $\left\{(0,0,x):x\in\mathbb{R}\right\}$, then $T$ is an isomorphism.
